column4: I want to install ubuntu to take up my entire drive, however i want to import the data from my current ubuntu installation (which is corrupt in the boot) yet ubuntu's installer wont let me. is there a workaround for this?
sorry, i was typing fast pepee. it means the /boot/ directory is GONE
even "grub-install"
the boot directory is completely corrupt, i cant repair this no matter what
but i've 15 gigs that i want to keep, yet reinstall ubuntu
i wish i could just get this damn vmlinuz. and linux-image, thing working
Have you tried this tut: http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?t=224351  <<< it worked for me many times
When you boot does GRUB load?
Can't you mount the partition from Debian and copy the files from there?
I asked you if you can mount it from within Debian and axx the files that way.
Why can't you partition it?
Don't you have any external storage devices?
Please lol. I am confused.
Is that Gparted on the ubuntu Live CD?
I don't think there's a difference, both do same thing.
Is that Gparted on the ubuntu Live CD?
You should try another partition program like cfdisk, or a Windows solution.
i dont have windows on this system at all
It could be that your hardrive is physically impaired. I had that and it was horrible.. you should run a surface test to see if it is physically defected.
its not my hard drive, i deleted the directory once by accident.
Talk about it, I resized my parititon yesterday, corrupted.. lost so much stuff :'(
Can't. Get external storage or free up space on the Debian partition.
Use different partitioning tools.
You don't need windows, these programs are booted into. Check 'Hiren's BootCD' for example.
